A total of 180 normo-ovulatory patients were randomly allocated to one of two stimulation protocols: a short-term (7-day) or long-term (14-day) gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist (GnRH-a) protocol. The results indicate that the short protocol is as effective as the long one in achieving a high number of mature follicles and embryos. The short protocol is convenient, easy to administer, and does not require the injection of exogenous gonadotropins. It is concluded that the short protocol is an acceptable alternative to the long protocol for patients with poor ovarian response..

Study #32: A prospective randomized trial comparing the efficacy of suprapubic and urethral catheters for postoperative urinary drainage after radical hysterectomy.. A prospective randomized trial was undertaken to compare the efficacy of continuous suprapubic and urethral catheters for postoperative urinary drainage following radical hysterectomy. One hundred and twenty-one patients were randomized into three groups: those with suprapubic catheters, those with urethral catheters and those with neither. Patients were followed up for a mean of 14 days (range 12 to 21 days) and the duration of catheterization was compared. Statistical analysis of the patients' voiding diaries showed that there was no significant difference in the volume voided between the three groups. The incidence of urinary tract infections was also similar. The results of this study indicate that there is no advantage in leaving catheters in situ for more than 3 days following radical hysterectomy..
